Hi everyone, I’m here to introduce my lean-quantum project, an implementation of the theory of quantum computing in the Lean programming language. It is completely based on Mr.Duckki Oe’s formal work #Program verification > Quantum Computing in Lean 3, but I converted it into Lean 4. https://github.com/guest2180/lean4-quantum

It took me about four months to convert most of the project and I learned a lot. There remain two files unconverted because they are not very related to other parts of the project and I’m lazy, but I proved the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle in addition. Because there are many differences between Lean 3 and Lean 4, the conversion is more like a reproof (rw) rather than a translation.

Warming: Most of the definitions, lemmas, and theorems are completely the same as the original work, so some of them may be outdated or of no use in the Lean 4 development environment. Besides, I’m really a green hand, so some naming styles and proof methods may be awful. And because I’m not good at writing elaborators, I just use some simple macros to replace metas in the original project, which may loop for a lot of times, resulting in low and slow compilation speed. To sum up, it would be better to just refer to my proof ideas and details, rather than simply reuse this project in another Lean 4 project (I believe it will cause a lot of trouble).

This project is open source on GitHub so everybody can use it. But it seems that I won’t modify this project for a long time, so I may not update this project even if someone offers some improvement ideas.

Oh sorry, it's available now.
This might be of interest to @Alex Meiburg , who created Lean-QuantumInfo
Obviously I'm a bit biased, but I think you should contribute to Lean-QuantumInfo, yes ;)

That repository's style was built on a considerably earlier Mathlib, and I would say that things have generally improved, overall; but also, there are some issues with theorems often omitting important assumptions simply because the types are insufficiently bundled

For instance, all of the no_cloning theorems talk about what it would take to clone a state given by (s : Vector 2^n). This is flawed, because it omits the requirement that the state be normalized.

The fact that there is no unitary U so that U * s = s ⊗ s is then a simple consequence of taking s to be any state of norm 2, and then the LHS has norm 2 while the RHS has norm 4.

This doesn't mean that the existing proof in the repo is built on the wrong ideas, in fact it looks fine, because it only ever use normalized states. So, it would be easy to fix the theorem statement to be correct, and the proof would still work with only small adjustments.

But it does mean that, in the current state, that no_cloning theorem would be quite hard to use in any downstream application, because a "good cloner" (for other purposes) only needs to clone unit vectors, not arbitrary vectors.
This leads to definitions like Ket and MixedState that bundle the appropriate properties together, and then you can be more relatively assured that you're stating what you intend to.

Altogether nice job getting the proofs ported to a modern version of Lean + Mathlib though.
Do you think you would be interested at all in porting the no cloning theorem to Lean-QuantumInfo? I'd be very happy to see some quantum computing PRs!
P.S. I've also tried to get a #Quantum information > channel events channel going, but atm it's pretty quiet in there :)

Alex Meiburg said:

For instance, all of the no_cloning theorems talk about what it would take to clone a state given by (s : Vector 2^n). This is flawed, because it omits the requirement that the state be normalized.

The fact that there is no unitary U so that U * s = s ⊗ s is then a simple consequence of taking s to be any state of norm 2, and then the LHS has norm 2 while the RHS has norm 4.

There is a unit definition for vectors, and adding it as a precondition might improve this theorem, as you mentioned. I also think ∀ vector is weaker than ∀ unit vector, so the latter remains correct if the former holds.

I'd be happy to try porting the theorem to Lean-QuantumInfo, provided you can share the definition of no-cloning in your repository's style and there exist some similar theorems (mainly those like kron_mixed_prod).
